name: places/ChIJ105rSB70wokRCLWGLSSdZK4
formattedAddress: 617-625 W 181st St, New York, NY 10033, USA
adrFormatAddress: 617-625 W 181st St, New York, NY 10033, USA

originalText.text: This place has gone so downhill over the past few years. Their doctors either don't have enough pediatric knowledge when it comes to kids or they just don't like seeing kids. Every single time I take my kid here to be seen because he's not feeling well; extremely congested and can barely breathe, vomiting, ear pain.. the doctors are always so dismissive or try to convince me that he's not sick or doesn't look sick. So I just brought him in for my own convenience or because I wanted to? I have to PUSH for them to even prescribe my kid anything to help with his symptoms when he's sick, because they just try to dismiss him without treating his symptoms. I remember the previous time I took my kid here a 2-3 months ago, the doctor we saw just kept going on about how "young" I look to even be a mom instead of just examining my kid. Today's doctor we saw came in with such an attitude like if he didn't even want to be there. Again, I had to continue asking for him to prescribe my kid anything before he finally did. Tried to tell me my kid is fine when clearly he's not which is why we're there in the first place. This place needs better professionalism and doctors before I recommend coming here.

originalText.text:
I checked in at the kiosk after speaking with someone at the front desk. There were three people ahead of me. I then waited for an hour to be seen. Meanwhile, I noticed several people who arrived after me had come and gone. I asked the woman at the desk why people who came in after me had been called first and had left. She asked for my name and birth date, and after checking her list flatly said, “You were checked out.”

What does that mean?

“You’ve already been seen by the doctor and you’ve been signed out.”

My head almost exploded. “I’ve been sitting in that chair for an hour waiting to be seen.” She replied, “Well, you’ve been seen by the doctor and you’ve been checked out.”

ExCUSE me??

“I haven’t been seen by ANYONE. How are you going to tell me that I’ve been seen, if I’ve been sitting in that chair for almost an hour? Why would I tell you that I’m waiting to be seen?”

She responded again, “Well, you’ve already been checked out.”

“Did you SEE me go back there to be seen? Did you see me return?”

At this point, another woman at the desk went to get someone to verify I was seen. When she returned with two men (I assumed one was a doctor and one was a medical assistant), they both looked confused. SHE looked up my birth date and appeared confused. The younger man, who I assumed was the medical assistant, decided to be proactive and asked me to follow him to a treatment room.

In the exam room, he apologized for the confusion. He said my name was called and someone else responded and was taken in to be seen. I was incredulous. First, I never heard my name called. I asked, “How is it possible that the wrong person was brought to the exam room and no one noticed? How is it that no one realized, ‘This is not the person we called?’ When I see my primary, every time someone walks into the room they ask for my name and birth date.”

He didn’t have an answer. He again apologized for the confusion.

Besides the insanity of taking in another patient under the wrong name, I am concerned that their medical information somehow gets incorporated into mine or vice versa. Is my medical insurance now somehow conflated with this random person?

I had gone to the CityMD  because I needed a lab verified negative Covid test, and I wanted to be checked out for another issue while I was there. At this point, I had no trust that the latter would be handled properly and I honestly just wanted to get out of there. I had them run the test, but I was livid from the experience.

This is not a location I will ever return to. Frankly, I’m not sure that I will use a CityMD again. This used to be a reliable place for professional, immediate medical attention. However, if this is an example of the current protocol - nope. It is understandable if there is a mistake in the patient queue, but if you cannot verify that you have the correct patient in front of you, a BASIC part of patient care - that is totally irresponsible and unacceptable.

originalText.text:
The wait was not too long, The room & facility was visibly clean. The technician who took my vitals was pleasant & quite professional.
My wife told the Dr. I shouldn't see what he was doing & I didn't.
I would definitely go again in a non life threating injury or for a vaccine should that arise.

originalText.text: Every time I’ve come in here I’ve received prompt, kind, excellent care. Last week Dr. Garcia and his tech team diagnosed my pneumonia right away; within an hour I was picking up my meds and on my way home to recuperate. The time before that, a gentle, keen-eyed doc found a splinter in my foot hours before I left for vacation. I feel lucky to have this terrific clinic in my ‘hood.

originalText.text: Midday on a Thursday, my wait time was between 90-120 minutes to be seen. The waiting room was packed full, and it was way too hot. They need a better way to shield the sun from the glass windows and walls. Please get some sun-blocking shades installed! I got overheated with my fever and they ended up having to call 911 for me.
